content: Act as a helpful AI assistant
In Julia, Given a DataFrame df_cars with column `model`, write a function `count_model_rows` that groups data by model and calculate how many rows there are for each.

In Julia, you can use the `groupby` function in the DataFrames package to group your dataframe by a certain column (in this case, "model") and then apply a function to count the number of rows in each group. Here's an example:

```julia
using DataFrames # Ensure you have this package installed in your Julia environment

function count_model_rows(df::DataFrame)
    grouped = groupby(df, :model) # Group dataframe by model column
    return nrow.(grouped) .- 1  # Subtract 1 to exclude the grouping column from count
end
```

You can then use this function on your `df_cars` DataFrame:

```julia
model_counts = count_model_rows(df_cars)
```

This will give you an array of counts for each unique model in the dataframe. The index of this array corresponds to the order of the models in `df_cars.model`.
